WRITING.TITLE: are there infinitely many numbers that appear exactly 4 times in Pascal's triangle?
WRITING.TEXT: it seems that all of the triangular numbers after 6 appear 4 times. just wondering if there are any proofs conjectures etc. for this. thanks.
this is what I meant thanks I figured there had to be a proof already for it somewhere
yes. sorry I worded it poorly

if there are 7 questions and 2 will be picked at random, since the order doesnt matter we have c(7,2) which means combination 7,2 or 7 pick 2. this gives us 21. there are 21 different arrangements of 2 unique elements from 7 unique elements. If you study 2 questions, your odds are 1/21. and you can kinda go from there

WRITING.TITLE: is this a known property of Pascals triangle?
WRITING.TEXT:
if the rows are represented as row 0, row 1, row 2, ....
then if row 1 = n, for each (n+1) and (n+2) after row 1, the rows (n+1) and (n+2) have the same number of unique numbers in that row. Examples... rows 2 and 3 have 1 unique number, rows 4 and 5 have 2 unique numbers, rows 6 and 7 have 3 unique numbers, rows 8 and 9 have 4 unique numbers

WRITING.TITLE: which theorem explains the technique to answer this combinatorics question?
WRITING.TEXT: In order to list the numbers 0 to 7 in binary notation, we need 12 1s (000, 001, 010, 011, 100, 101, 110, 111). How many 1s are needed to list in binary the numbers from 0 to 1023?
